name: 李老师不是你老师
content: Mr. Zhou Fengsuo refuted the rumors that a Fudan University student had been arrested recently, saying that he had spoken to the student and confirmed that he had not been arrested and was living a normal life.

name: 李老师不是你老师
content:
Some netizens found that the photos of Ni were all from her personal Weibo. In fact, her Weibo has been updated normally. Not only does she have daily life, but as a Messi fan, she has participated in the discussion of the World Cup. She also clarified on Weibo yesterday (now deleted) 
Therefore, the news about Ni's arrest is untrue.

name: 李老师不是你老师
content:
It is said that the person who posted the help information in the name of her classmate is currently unable to be contacted.
Some Twitter users are investigating who spread her photo in the name of protesting against the arrest and for what purpose.
I also urge all Twitter users to be cautious in handling such submissions containing personal information.

name: 李老师不是你老师
content:
In addition, many Twitter users are just speaking out for justice and are not deliberately spreading rumors. The main reason for this incident is that someone made a malicious post. Please be discerning and don't be too harsh.
It is obvious that this incident is now undermining the credibility of the Chinese Twitter community, and there may be more and more such incidents in the future.

name: 李老师不是你老师
content: @Ocho_Kawassaki First of all, I checked her Weibo account and found that she has been posting normally, and her friends are also interacting with her normally. Even if we control her account, it is difficult to fabricate a vivid scene, such as the content of getting a tattoo. In fact, if we want to make logical inferences, we might as well go back to the beginning, that is, how to prove that she was the first person to shout the slogan.

name: 李老师不是你老师
content:
@Ocho_Kawassaki Many people used my tweets as evidence when they spoke out, but the leader's face was not shown in the video, and this contributor did not submit directly to me, but used my tweets to submit to others.
If I were to infer, I would also think that someone was deliberately creating an incident in which I maliciously released information privately and then publicly refuted the rumor in order to undermine the credibility of other Twitter users.

name: 李老师不是你老师
content: Netizens contributed, according to the content of her circle of friends, we can see that she had been rumored before on Hupu

name: 李老师不是你老师
content: @Ocho_Kawassaki Your logic can be easily verified. Whoever questions it can provide evidence. You can do in-depth research on her Weibo to find out whether her statements are different from the past, whether the accounts that interact with her are zombies or real people, and how long they have been interacting with her, her posting frequency, her like frequency, and whether her behavior has been abnormal in the past month. Do your own research first, draw a conclusion, and then question it. This will be more convincing.
